title: How many 'hacking or malware (HACK)' data breaches will Privacy Rights Clearinghouse record for September 2017?
preds:
Comments: See @Mos September 29 post and comments. Good points. Up-vote 1. Going forward, see averages ticking up (+35) in the coming months as players (both state and non-state) ramp up attacks. Aligning forecast.
4 points:
1) State-actors: Russian success in this area + continued deterioration in USA/RU relations assures it's continuation. See same with IR, DPRK and PRC.
2) Non-state actors: Most [global] private sector, especially smaller organizations, still highly vulnerable. Intelligence/coordination still not fully shared among companies and industries. Risk mitigation efforts will continue to lag due to money.
3) Availability of advanced CIA/NSA hacking tools.
4) Existence of Wikileaks as a conduit for stolen data. Related:
CERT Coordination Center, CERT/CC: http://www.cert.org/
US Computer Emergency Readiness Team, US-CERT: https://www.us-cert.gov/

14 submittals with breach submission dates in September are still under investigation as reported by DHHS.  Even though the submittal of predictions on this board ends on Sept. 30, any of the DHHS submittals for September could resolve as hacks and then be added to the PRC database before October 31.   The count is currently 18 (as of 9/29) on the PRC database.  Only six submittals are needed to tip the count on the bucket from "between 15 and 23, inclusive" to "more than 23 but less than 31".  Seems like a sure thing to bet on the "between 15 and 23, inclusive" bucket. I'm sticking with "more than 23..." since April, May, July and August were 29, 27, 28, and 25 though June was only 17.  Is Sept. more like June or like the others?

Counted 17 today. The site does not get information and post information in a liner time format so it's just to unpredictable to assume 17 is the real number of attacks that have happened so far in reality.

Most of the MED hacks reported on the USDHHS site also show up on the same day on the Privacy Rights Clearinghouse database.  These reports must be easily authenticated.  A lesser number of MED hacks on the DHHS site are delay reported on the PRC database, perhaps due to the time required for verification of server traffic, email, etc.  The reporting on the DHHS website currently (9/29/2017) ends on Sept. 24.  The hacking appears to run in batches on certain days.   Appears that network servers are the most common route of attack, followed by email.  The least common route is desktop computer or laptop, presumably thumb drive.  Some of these attacks have signatures by multiple routes so not sure which one was first or if this indicates several visits.  Does anyone see a connection from hospital to clinic or vice versa?  If so, then there would be a geographic connection (proximity).  One might be able to map out the connections of the attacks.  Is the host server a common element?  Is this detail mentioned in the reports?  Take a look at record for 8/18/2017 on DHHS.  I'm certain that one could pull out patterns from the datasets then perhaps use that information for prediction.

Downloaded list today and hack cases are up to 17. 
The last one was the 26th and there is 4 days still to October. 
I believe  that if the current pattern holds there should be 2-4 new cases before the month ends.
Final update

"The question will be suspended on 30 September 2017 and scored using data downloaded from the online chronology on October 31."
--from description above Cases Currently Under Investigation--U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
https://ocrportal.hhs.gov/ocr/breach/breach_report.jsf Also note that the records in the Privacy Rights Clearinghouse appear to be dominated by MED category, at least for the most recent months.
Comments: To date, I counted 17, which included the latest Sonic breach. 3 days left in the month. Adjusting mix.
more could be reported in coming months and back dated to September
Rate appears to slow at end of month.
August jumped up to 26 breaches, and September jumped up to 13 breaches, as of today (9/25). Adjusting slightly, as that now has July and August above 23.

Excel file suddenly went up to 14 cases! last time I checked (22 sept) there were only 3.....this means a very late response to what is actually happening. 
- Since this challenge will actually check the file in October there will be plenty of time for the new incidents to be reported.
- Now, the average in September is around 5 hacks per week (most of them come from the first week). 
- There is still one week for September to be over and its very improbable that at least one more hack will not happen. Will update forecast once more at the end of the week

So, what is the greater probability:   1) The intern returned from vacation and caught up on his data entry, or  2) the office manager finally figured out the intern wasn't returning from vacation, and being the last one in the office on a Friday afternoon, caught up on the data entry herself.
The updating of the Privacy Rights Clearinghouse database is amateur to say the best.

I might be doing it wrong but when I download the file and follow the filter instructions I only see three incidents in September so far..... with less than 10 days before september ends I want to believe that more than 14 incidents has low prob...
Ten days left tells the story.
It depends how big of a hack is necessary to be counted. Because there are 100's of hacks every day and DDOS hostage situations.
Reports are fewer but attracting more publicity.
Most of the august breaches seem to be reported towards the end of the month (11/17 after Aug 15) so maybe a bump in the next two weeks. I simply don't believe only three.
As @Dsarin pointed out. We're currently at.... 2.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Comments: Moving into week 3 and getting somewhat uncomfortable here with only 2 entries posted on the site so far. WTF? Are they going to have a 'gotcha' with a final tally at month's end? I feel that we're at the mercy of ad-hoc reporting with 'Date Made Public'.  Making an incremental adjustment to CYA.
Very weird there's still only 2 so far.  Maybe the intern who inputs the data is on vacation?
Only two so far this month.
Half-way through the month and things are rather quiet.
We're seeing more data breaches occurring and I believe that at minimum wel'll recorded between 31-40, though I'm truly thinking it is actually ove 40
Still 17 for August and 2 for September
Redistributing according to known reports up to mid-September-very high number 40+ becoming less likely.
Taking essentially even odds on the over-under of 23.
17 in August. 28 in July. One really big one in September, but that only counts as one.
Comments: Going into 2nd week. See @seamusfag September 10 post and comments. Up-vote 1. Adjusting mix.
Breaches are happening at an alarming rate --I expect these will increase until the offence becomes a capital crime, worldwide.
17 in June, 28 in July, 17 in August so far, 2 so far in September. Revising down substantially
hit enter prematurely... this will change.

28 in July and 16 in August (so far). With the exception of March, which had 46, the range for 2017 has been between 15 and 29. If that trend continues, it will be an over-under on 23 breaches for September. Adjusting my forecast accordingly.

Across 2016 and 2017 so far, there has been an average of 30 HACK attacks a month. So far, month by month, 2017 has experienced fewer HACK attacks than 2016, so a lower figure for September is somewhat more likely.

This is quite the coin toss, but let's have a look at the data from the database. The numbers in the last 5 months fluctuated between 13 (in August, even if the database is not complete yet for August, maybe) to 30. Last year, September 2016 got 43 attacks, however it seems that 2016 was globally worse than this year (August 2016 got 31 attacks versus 13 this year; July 29 versus 28 this year; June 33 versus 17 this year...)
Even if September seems to be more active than the summer months, maybe we won't arrive at the peak of 2016. This makes me exclude the two extreme categories and give more weight to B and C.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

PCR records ~7600 data breaches since 2005, about 650/yr, ~50/mo. Are breach attempts increasing? Probably, as tools, knowledge of tools, and distribution of tools increase. The PCR site does not give a distribution or trend line for breaches. Is data security any better? Maybe, although that  information is not transparently available. The number of breaches reported probably does not include all breaches, because some organizations don't like their security failures to become public. Some breaches that organizations would not like to be reported likely will be for reasons beyond their control. The situation is murky.
hackers' learning curve seems to have accelerated, bitcoin more valuable

@cmeinel and @danbell7819 comments are incredibly insightful, I recommend them to anyone looking for good analysis. I'm going to be wishy-washy on this as I haven't found anything that gives me more confidence than their own work. Cheers to @Kiki-Roo for reminding me that the take down of Darkode in 2015 may skew the base rate numbers down.
Adjusting based on the August data, and knowing there will likely be a couple more breaches for August reported later next month.
361 year to date as of August 25, 2017.  That is an average of about 43 per month.  No reason to expect hackers to let up on their attacks.

Comments: Applying KISS principles. Did some hillbilly calculations and came up with: monthly average = 26 (206/8); incidents appear to be treading up with growing participation of state-sponsored actors.

OK, here's a modeling kluge seasoned with hand-waving that has persauded me to change my forecast bigly.  From the Privacy Rights Clearinghouse database, months August 2016 through July 2017:
Average/month 32 2/3
High 51
Low 19 * Basket between 15 and 23: 2 ~17% * Between 24 and 30: 2: ~17% * Between 31 and 40: 6 ~50% * Over 40: 2 ~17% Growth of most recent complete 12 months over previous 12 months: 30% Multiply data from each of the most recent months by 1.3 for projected baskets for Sept. 2017 Basket between 15 and 23: 0% Between 24 and 30: 2: ~17% Between 31 and 40: 6 ~50% Over 40: 4 ~33% However, given the month-to-month variability, I will need to watch the reported hacks as they occur during September. Computer criminals and officious self-described white hats are culturally heterogeneous so the September data will likely features mixtures of Murphy's Law, Lady Luck and the general cussedness of the Universe. CHAMPS KNOW checklist:  Yes -- Comparison classes.  Provide relevant classes and calculate base rates.
Yes -- Hunt for info. Share the evidence that helps inform your prediction.
Yes -- Adjust. Explain the reason for updating your prediction.
Yes -- Models. Explain any application of mathematical or statistical models.
Post-mortem. Interpret past failures and successes; draw implications for the future.
Yes -- Select effort. Describe the optimal level of effort.
N/A Know the power-players. Describe individuals with influence and how will they use it.
N/A Norms & protocols. Describe laws, rules, scheduled meetings, etc., that matter.
N/A Other perspectives. Describe bottom-up processes (protest, culture, market forces, technology, etc.) that may play a role.
Yes -- Wildcards. Explain the sources and magnitude of uncertainty. Please tell me if I messed up the spreadsheet calculations because to err is human, but to really eff things up requires a computer. @Mos @cdob63 @SneakyPete531 @Censusguyz @melancholy-aeon @seamusfag

The Shadow Brokers Have Made Almost $90,000 Selling Hacking Tools by Subscription, Researcher Says
https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/neejqw/the-shadow-brokers-have-made-almost-dollar90000-selling-hacking-tools-by-subscription-researcher-says
https://www.scmagazine.com/shadow-brokers-smb-exploits-use-complex-code-suggest-significant-resources-and-backing/article/682033/
http://www.itpro.co.uk/security/29234/shadow-broker-exploit-dumps-five-million-cyber-attacks It's yet to be seen if DPRK increases hacking activity beyond their current level but one could expect a rise in reports of increased hacking in near future.
TA17-164A: HIDDEN COBRA – North Korea’s DDoS Botnet Infrastructure
https://www.us-cert.gov/ncas/alerts/TA17-164A Signs of DPRK hacking?
https://www.kaspersky.com/about/press-releases/2017_chasing-lazarus-a-hunt-for-the-infamous-hackers-to-prevent-large-bank-robberies
Per the dataset, the 2017-to-date average is 25.333. This is an almost two percent drop from the 2016 average.
There have been 183 breaches reported in 2017 to date.  This averages at about 30 per month which is what I have used as a guide to base my forecast on
March seems to be an outlier which skews the average number per month high.

Purely statistics based. With 15, 24, 26, 29, 27, 15, and 24 attacks for each of the first seven months of the year, that  leaves a mean of 25.7 and a standard deviation of 10.5. Putting this in a normal distribution yields the curve provided above. I suppose a Poisson distribution would be a better fit, but I might save that for another day.

Based on the last 5 years of data, on four months have observed more than 40 HACKs, so this seems to be not as common. However, 3/4 have occurred in the last two years. While there have been 16 months with less than 15 events, there has not been a month with less than 15 in over a year.  The remained of the three choices appear relatively often (19, 16, 12 respectively) in the data and are fairly evenly dispersed across time.
2017 seems to have variation around about 25

In my previous forecast I had not realized there is a lag in reporting. And I had counted many reports twice. This forecast assumes a normal distribution with mean 32 and std dev 7, and a system of reporting lags.
Breaches were around 33/mo last year. Breaches have been going up. I estimate 20% more this year so ~39 but this is small number so chance of high variation.

Simple monte carlo using 2013-2017 data. Since the sample size was very small, I averaged the standard deviation of events by month for each year from 2013 to 2016 to smooth, which decreased the std from 14ish (way too evenly distributed across all buckets) to 6ish.  So far, 2017 is more like 2014 and 2016 in terms of volume of hacks (22 and 43 respectively). September is very average in terms of number of events, but with the highest year on year variance. Maybe I should have balanced between more between the September std and annual std of hacks instead of relying solely on the month to month deviation within a year. If adjusted, the probability of 'Less than 15' and 'Between 31 and 40' would increase 6-7% with a commensurate decrease in the middle bands.
Based on averaging publicly released breaches
Based on exponential interpolation of HACK type attacks from the database
Graph analysis  of reported incidence.  Cipher Block Chaining Mode with non recurring IV (the fall of the enigma code) will reduce hacking substantially as is comes online.

Apr 2016: 27, Apr 2017: 29
May 2016: 43, May 2017: 27
June 2016: 33, June 2017: 13
July 2016: 29. July 2017: 24
August 2016: 31
September 2016: 43
October 2016: 32
November 2016: 25
December 2016: 37 The number of reported attacks in 2017 are down considerably. Perhaps because companies are keeping it hidden and there hasn't been a massive data breach reported, making it more in vogue to report to the public at large any smaller breaches? I expect August and September to both be in the mid-20's and no higher than 35.

Building on the Jan 2015-July 2017 analysis of others and adding a bias of more hacks reported going forward.
Firms have been reluctant to report hacks in the past, I believe the mood is changing toward more reporting.
2017 YTD trend is slightly lower than 2016. August is very low but Europe is in vacation... so September 2017 should be around 25.
Current rates are over 100 per month

looked at 5 years, monthly average, noted the increase & decrease per year. This gives me a base similar to DariusX2. But also considered other public info that suggests hacking by foreign entities may be increasing, so I tossed a little more weight into that.
Major bobo - did not look at data myself

No seasonal pattern detected in 2016 and 2017. So, taking monthly averages for those two years and giving a tiny bit of weight to the very small downward trend. That's the base-case, and I don't see any reason to adjust it in either direction.
modeling the distribution of number of monthly hacks

There is a been quite a shift in TTP for attackers in the last 18 months and there has been few 'new' APT type penetrations reported. The lag between development of new attack methods and wide distribution of IOCs means that I expect to see a number of new IOCs for various types of malware and APTs shortly. This will lead to a spate of existing but undetected data breaches coming to the forefront. TTP: Tools, Tactics, Procedures; APT: Advanced Persistent Threat can refer to nation-state, financially, or ideologically motivated attackers, though the media and reports usually use it in context of nation-state attacks.
September 2016 had more than 40. But average per month is below 40 and I expect data security is improving more than hacking ability so anticipate some real possibility of a slow downward trend.
Modeled roughly on the distribution of hacking or malware hacks between the months of January and August 2017
Taking part in hybrid forecasting preparatory activities.

Reviewing the record from Jan 2015 - Jul 2017 shows a wide variation in publicly reported attacks from 13 - 46. The median was 25 with a std dev of 10. We are currently averaging 26 reported hacks/month in 2017. However, given the increasing availability of hacking tools for sale in the dark web/created by state institutions, I believe the distribution should be slightly skewed up.
This initial assessment is based solely on current 2017 numbers (Jan-15, feb-24, mar-46, apr-29, may-27, jun-13, jul-24).
More awareness of cyber attacks after WannaCry - so hacktavists aware of increased publicity, relative success of ransomeware, also victims more aware, so more attacks AND more reporting of attacks
It seems to fit the data
This is the historical trend for the year.

Looked at past 3 years history, to check average and trends. Then I tried to see if September was special (looked a little high-ish). I can imagine a possible big uptrend more easily than a big downtrend. Not sure I did my math correctly.
Total so far is 180, which puts the average at about 23 a month. General trend is up for hacking, so I put more weight in 23 < x < 31
Once something is hacked the knowledge of how it was hacked become more accessible before a stop-gap is inserted.
I'm not sure of the level of breach that is being considered. Seeking additional information
Based on 3-year monthly average as compared to September 2016 actuals.
Datra breaches are becoming more frequent, so above average is my expectation.  Would be useful to see a time graph of the number per month.
Increased activity by government foreign actors.

The number bounces around month to month so making predictions is difficult and since this is a short term forecast that excludes a lot of fundamentals in favor of noise I am going to stick with the average.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
On average reports about 50 per month, detection methods will improve, and attacks will also increase so the number reported is likely to be above 40
Based on other's comments, and conservatively spreading my bets.
Based on the to date number of breaches and then an assumption the per month number is increasing and not stable.
Following @Kiki-Roo on the basis of outstanding research and analysis. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/548466
The number of breaches per month has been relatively stable but it seems reasonable to expect an increase given current levels of activity and vulnerability.
avge this yr seems to be >40/mo
Hacking attacks are happening daily.  I believe they will find at least one each day.
Looking at the clearinghouse data from 2017 indicated about 25 attacks per month so far in 2017, and I see that as either being stable or slightly increasing.

This seems to me to be a relatively statistical question, there are always ways to corrupt a system, there are always improvements being made and there are always people looking to corrupt a system.  Recent trends should be indicative.

A crude pattern based on the data is the number of breaches recorded in July 2017 is between July 2015 and July 2016. This suggests a range between 13 and 43 for Sept based on that line of reasoning. Giving a bit more probability to higher ranges due to higher numbers over time. 2015 - 20 (July) 13 (Sept)
2016 - 29 (July) 43 (Sept)
2017 - 24 (July) ??
There have been almost 8000 breaches in the last ten years and the pace is accelerating.
Well, some crude math of their current data puts the estimate at around 200 hacks through  31 August, which is 25 per month.
Based on observed incident rate in the first part of 2017.
The Russian medling will lead to stricter legislation and passing of new cyber laws that will enact swifter punishments.
Distributed around the average I found.
I tend to read news about computer/data security.
I analyzed the data from the last several years and the frequency distribution seems to be pretty consistent.
Average per month for the year thus far is ~25 breaches. We should expect a curve centred on that number, with it being more likely to be higher than lower.
Based on the average distribution from data for Jan-Jul 2017.
Based on monthly histogram analysis since 2014 (discounting older data).

Looking back at 5 years of PRCCoDB data, I feel the higher probability would go to 31-40 as an average. While there is an overall statistical rise in September incidents reported, there is a marked dip in 2015 which could be due to the take down of Darkode (1), and a rise in 2016 which could have been due to the U.S. Presidential Elections. I predict that the trend will even out between 31-40 in 2017. 1. https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/cyber-criminal-forum-taken-down

Using Privacy Rights Clearinghouse's data, the average monthly number of breaches has been 25/mo for 2017. Taking out the highest (Feb, 46) and lowest (Jun, 13), the monthly average drops to 24/mo. Since the range this year has been between 13 and 46, it seems plausible for all of these options to be viable. We'll see how August shakes out and adjusts the average, but right now I'm going fairly conservative.
Historically, it appears to average around 30 a month, usually a little higher but it seems to have declined a little this year.

Breaches of the type mentioned in this question have averaged about 25 for the previous three years and seven months. As any given month can fluctuate significantly (don't have monthly data to evaluate), I am going to split between the two closest intervals.

Breaches of the type mentioned in this question have averaged about 25 for the previous three years and seven months.  So we are a bit on the bubble here between two intervals.  There has been some significant fluctuation during this time interval.  So I am going to split to the middle with a slight bias to the number that holds the 25 incident number.

Data shows such breaches have been and continue to be on the rise.  Actual Hacks far exceed reported hacks for a variety of reasons.  Unfortunately, most organizations and governments have been unable to meet the challenges presented by hackers, especially  hacks coming from state sponsored actors.

If I understand the question correctly, my answer is that I believe there will be more than 40 breaches in September because the number of breaches has not been below 40 per month from January 2016 through July 2017.  While I am sure that companies are taking more precautions there are probably more people hacking.

Examining the data that will be used to calculate the final number, we find that there are only 180 incidents that match the criteria to date. 180 spread over 7 months means roughly 25 per month, so we select percentages centered on 25% but skewing high, as the data also show a gradual increase in the number of incidents over time.
News of hacking incidents is ubiquitous.
I am a hobby hacker.  The way that most network administrators approach network security is backwards.
On average, YTD, 21.6 breaches have been completed.
it seems to be a completely unregulated and open space, high reward and low risk crime
This seems to be roughly the current rate and there is no a priori reason to think it will decline

The monthly average for 2016 is > 60 and the current 2017 average is still 60. I don't think there has been any change that would cause the number of hacking attempts to go down, nor any change that makes data more secure.
